author: Sophie Williams
title: Fire on Hong Kong subway breaks out injuring at least 13
text:
A fire broke out today on a Hong Kong subway train during rush hour.
According to local police, the blaze was caused by a passenger, 60, who had set a carriage on fire as the train was about to arrive at the Tsim Sha Tsui station at 7:15pm local time.
Police have arrested the man on suspicion of arson.
A fire broke out on a Hong Kong subway train today after a passenger set a carriage on fire
The fire broke out in the last carriage of a train when it was about to arrive at Tsim Sha Tsui
Shocking: A commuter pours liquid over the man with his underpants on fire
The man then lies on the floor after commuters beat the fire out with their clothes
Video on social media shows the aftermath of the blaze and a man with his trousers completely ripped off.
The Hong Kong Fire Services Department posted a live-stream update on Hong Kong Police's Facebook page saying: 'A total of 13 people were injured, including four men and nine women.'
Yau Chi On, Assistant Chief of Kowloon's District Fire Services said the fire broke out in the last carriage of a Tsuen Wan bound train on the Tsuen Wan line.
Those injured have been taken to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Kwong Wah Hospital, Caritas Medical Centre and Prince of Wales Hospital.
The station remains closed following its evacuation.
Images from the incident show the injured being evacuated on stretchers.
A total of 13 people were injured, including four men and nine women, said the local authority
Police officers guard an entrance to Tsim Sha Tsui subway station in Hong Kong today
The fire was caused by a 60-year-old passenger who had set the train on fire
A Twitter account updated by passengers and MTR staff announced at 7:32pm local time: 'The Tsuen Wan Line accident was due to a passenger igniting dangerous goods.
'Police and fire have been called to the scene. The process has moved to the platform of the station. Tsien Wan Line trains will not stop at Tsim Sha Tsui station.'
At around 10pm local time, a spokesman from the police confirmed to reporters that the fire had been caused by a passenger who had set a carriage on fire.
This was confirmed by Kwok Pak-chung, the District Commander at the Yau Tsim District Police Station, during the live-stream video.
Mr Kwok said the suspect had admitted the act to one of the police officers while he was being transferred to hospital.
The suspect has been identified by his surname Cheung and he is said to be 60 years old.
Passengers were left choking as the smoke engulfed the carriage in Tsim Sha Tsui
Smoke filled the carriage causing chaos during rush hour on Hong Kong's MTR system
A commuter who saw the incident unfold told Hong Kong Free Press : 'The smoke came from nowhere and spread very quickly - I just took a photo then I had to use my jacket to cover my nose.'
Footage from the aftermath of the incident shows commuters shouting and fleeing the scene.
A man can be seen on the floor of the platform with his trousers burnt off and his underwear on fire.
Two commuters try and beat the fire to stop the flames.
While the fire in the carriage continues to grow.
Some commuters can be seen trying to take pictures as the fire alarm sounds.
The police are carrying out further investigation into the case.
